feed.title: Review: Battlefield 3
feed.subtitle: As far as first-person shooters go, the franchise has managed to do just about everything right.

category.term: Dr. Ing. h.c. F. Porsche AG
category.label: Company

link.Abstract: Vancouver street soccer players—the unrestricted athletes who bring their panache and personalized style to unlined parks, gymnasiums and backyard laneways—will recognize Vancouver in the upcoming FIFA Street, created by Electronic Arts and available in March for Playstation 3 and Xbox 360.
link.title: Jock and Jill: FIFA Street references Vancouver

category.term: Dr. Ing. h.c. F. Porsche AG
category.label: Company

content.div:
Platforms: X360, PC, PS3

The Deal: It's been more than six years of painful waiting as DICE laboured over the next installment of its phenomenal "Battlefield" series. As far as first-person shooters go, the franchise has managed to do just about everything right, offering everything from massive environments to diverse vehicular combat. Unfortunately, during its hiatus, several companies built blockbuster shooters that have forced nearly every thought of "Battlefield" from consumers' minds. But as the saying goes, It's about quality, not quantity, and if you want quality, you want "Battlefield 3."

I could spend hours discussing single-player stories and gameplay, but as far as "Battlefield" is concerned, being excited over single-player is the same as being excited over the sound system in your new Porsche. Sure, it's there and it's great, but it's not the real reason you spent all that money on the car. However, for those who want to know, there is a single-player campaign that places you on the Iran/Iraq border fighting against the People's Liberation and Resistance. If the combat is just too tough for you, invite a friend and play it together in the game's co-op mode.

Once you've tried your hand at single-player and developed a feel for the controls, try the game's multiplayer and see where the "Battlefield" series truly shines. With the ability to host 24 players on the consoles and a whopping 64 soldiers on the PC, "Battlefield 3" is sure to make the war epic as you compete with gamers from around the globe.

Sheer numbers aside, the game also boasts the newly developed Frostbite 2 engine. This technological miracle is responsible for the ultrarealistic graphics that look more like footage from CNN and less like a game. The engine is also responsible for the game's destructible environments, which levels cover, causes buildings to collapse and unearths every tree that stands in the path of war.

So now you have a lot of people fighting across gorgeous landscapes, but what else could the game possibly offer? Well, if you enjoyed the selectable classes of "Battlefield 2," you can breathe a sigh of relief, because they're back and looking better than ever. Each class comes complete with its own equipment and role, from the heavy machine-gun-wielding Support or the stealthier Recon. Finally, fans will be thrilled to see that a pile of vehicles is ready for use, from the high-flying jets and helicopters to the game-changing tanks.

Media Link: "Strike Back" airs Friday, Oct. 28, on Cinemax.

entry.title: Nintendo's loss swells to $925 million for first half

link.Abstract: Nintendo said Thursday its net loss swelled to 70.3 billion yen ($925 million U.S.) for the six months to September as it forecast a full-year loss, citing the strong yen and a lack of hit game titles.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Nintendo said Thursday its net loss swelled to 70.3 billion yen ($925 million U.S.) for the six months to September as it forecast a full-year loss, citing the strong yen and a lack of hit game titles. In the photo guests at a Nintendo party celebrate the launch of Nintendo's Super Mario 3D on November 3, 2011 in Hollywood, California.
link.title: Nintendo losses

link.Abstract: Photos from the launches for video games like Call Of Duty, Batman, and Mario 3D.
link.title: Gallery: Blockbuster video game launches

link.Abstract: Despite all the advancements in computing technology over the past decade, there's still one human sense that continues to baffle computer scientists: scent.
link.title: Smells like success

link.Abstract: Sales of what retailers are calling the year's most hotly anticipated video game hit the bull's-eye Tuesday as hordes of local gamers joined thousands of others worldwide hoping to be among the first to purchase Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3.
link.title: Gamers answer Call of Duty

entry.title: Jock and Jill: FIFA Street references Vancouver
entry.summary: Electronic Arts soccer franchise doesn’t include women avatars

link.Abstract: Vancouver street soccer players—the unrestricted athletes who bring their panache and personalized style to unlined parks, gymnasiums and backyard laneways—will recognize Vancouver in the upcoming FIFA Street, created by Electronic Arts and available in March for Playstation 3 and Xbox 360.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: A screen cap from FIFA Street UK.
link.title: FIFA Street

link.Abstract: The Canadian national men's soccer team is on the rise - a slow rise.
link.title: Canadian men gain four spots in FIFA rankings

link.Abstract: Three years after EA went from being one of the hottest kids on the video games block to industry also-ran, the leaner, more focused company now hopes to take on Zynga and make $3 billion in revenue from digital game sales in the next few years.
link.title: EA wants Facebook's users, $3 billion in social gaming

link.Abstract: Electronic Arts Inc will launch its multiplayer role-playing game "Star Wars: The Old Republic" just before the Christmas holidays in Europe and North America, but fans in Asia will have to wait longer to pick up their lightsabers online.
link.title: EA's Star Wars set for late December launch

link.Abstract: Brenda Bailey Gershkovitch can spot a bottle of ketchup on a crowded kitchen counter from 20 feet away, but her husband and teenage sons couldn't find the condiment if they were standing right next to it.
link.title: As video game market grows so do women followers

entry.content: Vancouver street soccer players—the unrestricted athletes who bring their panache and personalized style to unlined parks, gymnasiums and backyard laneways—will recognize Vancouver in the upcoming FIFA Street, created by Electronic Arts and available in March for Playstation 3 and Xbox 360.
